div.opener: Dublin May 31st. 1841 on my way home to Edgeworthstown to which place please to direct yr next My dear Dr. Sprague
div.p:
I have not received any letter from you short or
long since that which you received from me
in the winter in which I acknowledged the
receipt of your kind & munificent present (if it be a present) of
Sillimans Journal - I told you that I had concieved
the books had been sent to me by either Mr. Ralstone
or the Ticknors till they assured me that they knew
nothing about the matter - & I asked you in my last letter
to let me know distinctly whether I had commissioned
you to procure these Sillimans Journal for me or
whether you voluntarily sent them as a present to me
And I besought you to answer this question candidly
that I might not unknowingly encroach upon your
kindness and liberality - I never ~~ that I can re~
collect recollect , ~ received an answer to this question - I took
the liberty of adding a list of the numbers of Sillimans
Journal which are deficient in the bound & unbound
volumes which I have received from you - I will send a
duplicate list of these deficient numbers ordered in this letter

You say that you had intended sending me "several
of the last Nos. of Sillimans Journal but that my
last letter left you in doubt whether I was receiving
it from some other friend and you say you had
better wait till you hear from me again rather than
run the risque of burthening me with duplicate No

From this observation I perceive that you
cannot have received my last letter in which I certainly
fully explained to you that I did not receive Silliman's
Journal from any friend except yourself - And that
I never knew that I was indebted to you for them till you informed
me that you had sent them - I am really concerned
that my letter of thanks has never reached you as
you have reason to think me very negligent and
ungrateful for so much attention and kindness -

You say in your last of April 26th - 41 that you
beq
avail yourself of the kindness of a gentleman from
Abany Albany
who was about to cross the ocean to send me
a couple of little volumes which has excited interest
in your country - the correspondance of the wife of the
elder President Adams - I am very much obliged
to you my dear Sir - But I never have received
these volumes - Perhaps I shall hear of them soon either
from Captn. Beaufort or No. 1 N. Audley Stt . Also of the skreen which
you tell me your eldest daughter (Charlotte has been
so kind as to make for me - I should be particularly
sorry to lose that skreen - pray express this to Miss
Sprague for me and assure her that I will write
to thank her as soon as the skreen shall reach me
or as soon as I can ascertain where it is - or is not

I have spent the last five months - from the
10th. of Dec.r to the 29th. of this month in England
- at No. 1 North Audley Street chiefly, entirely indeed
excepting one week at Brighton and a few
days in visits near London to old friends -
I have scarcely been out in London at all, having
refused all parties and all dinner visits on account
of the health and situation of my dear sister Fanny
(Mrs. Wilson wife of Lestock Wilson - though I did not
tell you her name I see I gave you an idea of her
character - And you would have a still better idea
of it if I could describe to you the patience, the sweet
ness of temper, the resignation with which she has
during all these months borne confinement &
privation and discipline and medicining not to repose
and almost constant pain - and yet enjoying literature &
never letting the smallest kindness of friend or
husband or servant even pass unnoticed by word of thanks
or look more expressive than words - She is the very
reverse in manner and character of that sort of
woman whom the poet in his "Rise of Woman"
describes
"Who makes a servant where she finds a friend"
on the contrary she has made friends where
she found only servants - I have seen how much
& truly friends her servants have shewn themselves
in their services and their feelings during her long
Illness - At last she was disappointed & so was
her husband (for the third time) disappointed in the
hopes of the blessing they so much wished for of a child

My poor sisters child was at the end of seven
months - still born - and when her husband
had piously and tenderly forgotten his or conquered
his disappointment for the loss of the child in his
thanksgiving that the wife (mother no more) was
spared to him, She was after the first weeks promise
of excellent recovery better than could be expected
taken dangerously ill with sudden internal
inflammation - pulse 140 - one night we des~
paired despaired - But by the courage & skill of her physician
thank God she has been saved - To give you an
idea of the danger & the decision & courage in meeting
it with desperate remedies - She had 74 leeches
applied in 24 hours and Calomel ~~ I dare not
say how much - She is now convalescent -
six weeks have elapsed - and tho I say convalescent
she is still lying on a sofa not able to stand or
walk - But she is improving in strength appetite
and sleep ~~~ spirits never failed - and have
been kept up by all the resources of literature &
of a mind highly cultivated in every way -
She is now at Brighton in a charmingly situated
house on Brunswick terrace in view of the sea &
refreshed by sea breezes which her physician assures
us will supply the place of calomel medicine alloy the and invigorate
her speedily - I had the happiness of seeing her
settled
in that delightful residence last week & leaving her
in the care of her own younger sister - (Mrs. E's
se-
cond second married daughter Harriet Butler the wife
of Revd Richard Butler Rector of Trim in the Cy. County of Meath)

She came over to supply my place with (Fanny)
Mrs. Wilson and she brought with her two young
nieces of 12 and 10 years old, Mary Anne & Charlotte
daughters of a sister we have lost (Sophy Fox -
Mr
& Mrs. Butler have always since their mothers
death taken charge of them - as their own - they
have no children of their own - Their father Captn
Barry Fox is also now with them at Brighton and
there they can have good masters for drawing dancing & music

Now my good dear Sir you see how in consequence
of your kind reproach that I did not tell you one of my
sisters names I have bored you with all my family history

The history of your Oxford robber, Doctor
divinity and Master of Arts is most astonishing and
disgraceful - I cannot conceive what his motive could
be for he could not possibly preach the sermon without
its being known or publish it without it being claimed
as yours - It seems to have been an abstract & inherent
love of stealing that possessed him - Such a passion has
been really known to exist in some noble families in our
old world - All the daughters thieves or sons swindlers
- a son of a noble house of England is at this instant a banish
ed banished man in consequence of having stolen his sisters diamonds
- and another of the first Barony in England was within
these few years publickly disgraced & compelled to fly his
country for cheating at cards - Of the Church I will say nothing
tho since the time when Dr. Dodd was hanged for forgery and
Dr. Johnson you know wrote a petition for pardon for him
Some more unpardonable offences have disgraced what ought
to stand highest in national estimation our clergy - That I
may deal fairly between England and Ireland I will
give you an amusing Irish placard - Epigram set up in the last
century at the entrance of the avenue of an Irish nobleman
in whose family this stealing propensity was known to prevail
- At the entrance to his parish there was a finger post
pointing the way and on the post was drawn a huge hand pointing the way
image of finger pointing
Great Baltinglass couldst thou command
Promethean fire to warm this hand
And couldst thou to this hand give feeling
Lord! What a hand t'would be for stealing

I must not end with scandal, so my dear
Dr. Sprague I will copy for you some lines
which in a literary Hue and Cry have been set
up - to convict our admired and excellent friend
clerical young poet Wolfe of having stolen from
the a Frenchman the ideas of his beautiful
lines on the death of Moore .

In Bentleys Miscellany Vol 1 there is an article
headed "The original of "Not a drum was heard

& then comes
this paragraph two short lines are circled

"The Revd Mr Wolfe is supposed to be the author
"of a single poem unparalleled in the English
"language for all the qualities of a true lyric, breathing
"the purest spirit of the antique and setting criticism
"completely at defiance. I say supposed for the gentle~
"=man gentleman himself never claimed to authorship during
"his short & unobtrusive life time. He who would write the
"funeral of Sir John Moore must have eclipsed all the
"lyric poets of this latter age by the fervour & brilliancy of his
"powers. Do the other writings of Mr. Wolfe bear any
"trace of inspiration? - none - I fear we must look
"elsewhere for the origin of those beautiful lines
"And I think I can put the public on the right scent"
"In 1749 Coll. de Beaumanoir a native of
Britany Bretagne
having
"raised a regiment in his own neighbourhood went
"out with it to India in that unfortunate expedition com=
"=manded commanded by Lally Tolendal, the failure of which even=
"=tually eventually lost to the French their possessions in Hindostan
"The Coll. was killed defending against the forces of Coote
"Pondicherry the last strong hold of the French in that
"hemisphere; he was buried that night on the North
"bastion of the fortress by a few faithful followers &
"the next day the fleet sailed with the remainder of
"the garrison to Europe - In the appendix to the
"Memoirs of Lally Tolendal by his son the following
"lines occur, which bear some resemblance to those
"attributed to Wolfe - Perhaps Wolfe Tone may have
"communicated them to his relative the clergyman
"on his return home"
signed P. Prout

p.foreign:
"Ni le son du tambour, ni la marche funebre
Ni le feu des soldats ne marqua son depart.
Mais du brave a la hâte, a travers les tenebres
Mornes, nous portaines le cadavre au rempart

2
De minuit c'etait l'heure - et solitaire & sombre
La lune a peine offrit un debile rayon,
La lanterne luisait peniblement dans l'ombre
de la bayonette on creusa le gazon

3
D'inutile cercueil ni de drap funeraire
Nous ne designames point entourer le heros
Il gisait dans les plis du manteau militaire
comme un guerrier qui dort son heure de repos

4
La priere quil fit fut de courte durée
Nul ne parla de deuil, bien que le coeur fut plein
Mais on fixait du mort la figure adorée
Mais avec amertume on songeait au demain

5
Au demain, quand ici ou sa fosse s'apprête
Ou son humide lit on dresse avec sanglots
L'ennemi orgueilleux marcha sur sa tête
Et nous ses Veterans seront loin sur les flots

6
Ils terriront sa gloire - On pourra les entendre
Nommer l'illustre mort d'un ton amer - ou fol,
Il les laissera dire - Et qu'importe a sa cendre
Que la main d'un Breton a confièe au sol.?"

div.p:
Now it seems wonderful to ME that
Mr. Prout (himself a man of talents) should
be so misled by the love of raising a hue & cry of
"Stop Plagiarist" as not to discern the difference between
the Plagiarist & the original Genius - It is sufficently
obvious that Lally Tolendal's is the copy, and
Wolfe's the original - That Lally Tolendal "made
the ideas his own" as Bayes in the Rehearsal expresses himself
and translated them into his own words and
applied them - to his own purpose for his own
friend Col Beaumanoirs funeral - The transla
tion translation is very creditable for a Frenchman, & for French
verse; but there is more difference between the transla.
tion translation and the original than Cervantes's allowance
for tolerably good translation ie as much as between the wrong
& the right side of tapestry. = I should say there is full
as much, as between English sterling gold and French
plating or French fillagree work. - All the lyric fervour
all the classical simplicity is lost in the base tawdry imitation

Since I wrote the remarks in the preceding
pages upon Mr. Prouts criticism I have
seen his publisher who informs me
that Mr. Prout during his whole literary
career which is now finished he being dead delighted
in literary quizzing - and that almost
all his publications are written either ironically
or in jest to take in the reader or see how
well he cd defend the wrong side or the
incredible - What a waste of time & talents
and I am sorry I have wasted your
eyes & time in reading so much that
I have here written to you about him

He was a native of Cork and
a priest who amused himself thus diverly foolishly

I will now bid you Adieu my dear Sir
regretting again that I Cannot thank your
daughter as I ought and tell her how I like
the skreen which she has made for me - Whether
I ever see it or not, whether it ever reaches me or
not let her be assured however that I feel the kindness
div.closer:
& I am your obliged & grateful
Maria Edgeworth
